posts.name: Izzy Haladjian
posts.cooked:
A few weeks ago, we switched from SDS MK3s to MK4is and started having significant drift while attempting to drive straight. We are using the same code (a modified version of the 364 BaseFalconSwerve) with the only changes being changing constants (CAN IDs and motor reversals). We are using falcons, CANcoders, and a Pigeon 2.0 and we have on-falcon PID on both drive and azimuth motors. Here is a quick list of the troubleshooting we have done:

-CANCoder magnets are glued down -Ensured that gears are greased well enough and there isn’t too much friction (helped slightly) -Loosened the bolts on the wheels to decrease friction (helped slightly) -Played with azimuth and drive on-falcon PID

We have now spent over a week working on implementing the solution found in the thread here: MK4 drift We wrote a gyro feedback method and struggled to get the PID tuned in, but we eventually got it to the point where it oscillated slightly but was driveable. We spent about a week on this and still can’t get the oscillating to stop. We continued driving back and forth and the drift had actually gotten worse and this method was doing absolutely nothing to help. I can’t understand why all of this isn’t working.

-Our code can be found here , the newly added gyro feedback method is in SwerveDrive.java under the commands folder -A video of the drift without the gyro feedback method can be found here . It has gotten a little bit better with some of the troubleshooting above but after a few minutes of driving, it is sometimes 90 degrees off

Any feedback would be greatly appreciated!

There are many factors that can cause drifting like this, and a solution is to use the gyro in a feedback loop. To stop oscillating you’ll just need to tune the PID loop better. Try increasing D or decreasing P. Do not use I for this.

In my research of swerve, it seems that this kind of chassis drift is all but impossible to avoid (without gyro feedback). Minor differences in the modules, loose carpet, not perfectly flat ground, unequal weight distribution, and many more things can cause drift.

The drift in your video is quite extreme however, so there may be some underlying mechanical, electrical, or software issue causing it. Put your robot upside down or on stilts or something and check that all the modules are precisely lined up when just translating. If they’re not that could also be causing drift. Make sure all your CANCoder status lights are green, make sure all the offsets are accurate and precise, make sure you’re using the right gear ratio to convert to TalonFX encoder counts, etc.

Using field relative control makes drift matter a lot less, since only rotation gets thrown off, not position. Then a driver can easily adjust the rotation as needed. I would assume that in a match, there aren’t many times where you’re driving in long straight lines without rotating at all, so drift wouldn’t really affect anything.

disclaimer: my team hasn’t ever fielded a swerve but I’ve been programming swerve for around 6 months now

Some thoughts:

As said before, make sure each module is zeroed correctly. My team likes to use a piece of 2x1 tube to make sure the wheels are parallel.

Also, make sure your 12V power wires aren’t near your pigeon. We have had some problems with the magnetic fields interfering with our gyro on previous years’ robots.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Time is valuable. Waste it wisely.

posts.custom_user_title: Time is valuable. Waste it wisely.

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan

link_counts.title: MK4i Swerve Module – Swerve Drive Specialties

posts.name: Izzy Haladjian
posts.cooked: This seemed to be the problem. Just needed a second set of eyes Now we just have some normal rotational drift that we will fix with a feedback loop. Thank you!

posts.name: Saikiran Ramanan
posts.cooked:
No problem.

If you haven’t done so, I would recommend removing the drift correction control loop and any of the other changes you may have made to try to combat the previous drift issue. From what I have seen so far, the combo of Pidgeon 2.0/Falcons/Cancoders/MK4is with very simple code (ie the 364 BaseFalconSwerve) works incredible well with minimal drift in the time frame of a match. Other larger mechanical or configuration issues may be masked by keeping this in for the time being until you are certain there are no other underlying issues.

posts.name: Izzy Haladjian
posts.cooked: Thank you for the suggestion, I will do that

suggested_topics.excerpt: I dont know how to show code but everything else works except our wheels and now they wont aline properly half work half dont and then they all break vide…

accepted_answer.excerpt: I haven’t looked through everything too detailed, but this stuck out at me first glance. Your azimuth gear ratio is set to 150/7.1 : 1 while according to the SDS website, the real azimuth gear ratio is 150/7 : 1.
